text: IRM 6.610.1 provides Service-wide policy, standards, requirements, and guidance relating to the administration of hours of duty and work schedules. This IRM must be read and interpreted in accordance with pertinent law, Governmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Resources Directives, as well as applicable case law. Previously official Servicewide policy, guidance, requirements, and authorities formerly contained in the IRS Time and Leave Handbook, memoranda, guides, and other documents are incorporated into this IRM if current and applicable.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM is new. It supersedes the sections of IRM 6.600.1, Leave Administration and Work Scheduling, published January 1, 2003 that pertain to scheduling work and work schedules (parts 6.600.1.1 through 6.600.1.7.4). A new IRM 6.630.1, Absence and Leave, concerning the leave administration section of IRM 6.600.1 (part 6.600.1.8) will be published separately.

This Chapter provides policy guidance on hours of duty and work schedules for the IRS. As required, it will be supplemented by Human Capital Office (HCO) interim policy guidance periodically issued by the IRS Human Capital Officer. As this Chapter is updated in the future, the interim guidance will be incorporated into the IRM. The manual is organized for consistency along the general order of the regulations found in 5 CFR 610. To provide more detailed references, hyperlinks are included to access supporting documents and information located on the IRS intranet and Office of Personnel Management (OPM) web site. Unless otherwise indicated, the policies, authorities, proce- dures, and instructions contained in this Chapter apply to all IRS
6.610.1.2 (08-14-2009) Scheduling Work and Work Schedules
This section provides policy, procedures, and guidance on weekly and daily scheduling of work, including flexible and compressed work schedules.
(cid:
) Administrative Workweek - An administrative workweek is a period of seven consecutive
hour periods, designated within the IRS as beginning at
A.M. Sunday and ending at
midnight Saturday. (cid:
) Basic Workweek -The basic workweek means the days and hours within an administrative workweek that employees are regularly scheduled to work.

The days and hours within an employee’s regularly scheduled workweek, during which the employee is required to be on duty, may also be referred to as the ″basic work requirement.” Employees are expected to fulfill their basic work requirement (each hour, day, workweek, or pay period) through the completion of assigned work and/or approved leave status.
(cid:

) Tour of Duty - A tour of duty consists of the hours during the day (a daily tour of duty) and the days of an administrative workweek (a weekly tour of duty) that constitute an employee’s regularly scheduled administrative workweek. (cid:
) Standard Tours of Duty - The standard basic workweek throughout the IRS consists of five consecutive
-hour workdays, Monday through Friday, in each administrative workweek.
Regular Schedule - Sometimes referred to as a straight/8 work schedule, this is a traditional work schedule that requires full-time employees to work 8 hours
Hours of per day and
hours per week, over five workdays, generally Monday Friday and with two consecutive non-workdays. Each day’s tour is the same. (cid:
) Alternative Work Schedule (AWS) - Work schedules established under U.S.C.
that consist of both flexible and compressed work schedules. (cid:

) Flexible Work Schedule (FWS) - A work schedule that allows an employee to determine a schedule within established limits. Within IRS, only approved flexible work schedule is flexitour with credit hours, which allows an employee to select starting and stopping times within flexible hours. Once selected, the hours are fixed until an opportunity is provided to select different starting and stopping times. (cid:
) Compressed Work Schedule (CWS) - A fixed work schedule, that for a full-time employee, the basic
-hour biweekly work requirement is completed in less than
workdays, e.g.,
and
In the case of part-time employee, the biweekly basic work requirement is completed in less than
workdays and may require the employee to work more than eight hours in a day. (cid:
) Regular Overtime Work - Overtime work that is part of an employee’s regularly scheduled administrative workweek is referred to as “regular overtime work.” (cid:
) Irregular or Occasional Overtime Work - Overtime that is not part of an employee’s regularly scheduled administrative workweek is considered irregular or occasional overtime work. (cid:
) Full-Time Employees - Full-time employees are regularly scheduled to work
hours in a week on the days specified in the basic workweek, or for employees on a compressed work schedule,
hours in a pay period on the days specified within the pay period. (cid:
) Part-Time Employees -
Part-time employment means regularly scheduled work from
to
hours per week (or from
to

hours per pay period) performed by employees with career or career conditional appointments or permanent appointments in the excepted service (as defined by the Federal Part- Time Career Employment Act or PTCA).
Seasonal employees with part time work schedules are also included under PTCA requirements.
Employees who were on a permanent, part-time schedule before April
, may work any amount of hours fewer than
hours per week as long as they remain in that or any other permanent part-time position without a break in service of more than three calendar days.
For additional information regarding part-time employment, including job sharing, see http://hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/internalplac/employprog/ ptemploy/ and IRM
, Establishing and Changing Part-time of Duty. (cid:

) Intermittent Employees - Intermittent employees have no regularly assigned work schedule and no prescheduled tour of duty. Intermittent schedules are appropriate only when the nature of the work is sporadic unpredictable such that a tour of duty cannot be regularly scheduled in advance. Business units may schedule an intermittent employee’s work a maximum of two consecutive pay periods without changing their work schedule to full-time or part-time. (cid:
) Seasonal Employees -
Seasonal employees are employed for one or more seasons each calendar year and retained on the rolls in nonpay status between
Seasonal employees are employed for one or more seasons each calendar year and retained on the rolls in nonpay status between
of Duty and Work Scheduling 6.610.1

Seasonal employees are released to nonpay status and recalled to duty accordance with pre-established conditions of employment. Seasonal employees may work full time, part time, or intermittent work schedules. For additional information regarding seasonal employment, see http:// hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/internalplac/employprog/seasemploy/ and IRM
, Use of Seasonal Appointment Authority.
Seasonal employees may work full time, part time, or intermittent work schedules.
For additional information regarding seasonal employment, see http:// hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/internalplac/employprog/seasemploy/ and
, Use of Seasonal Appointment Authority. (

) An employee’s tour of duty must be documented, identifying the calendar and hours of the day, and made a matter of record. The tour of duty must be documented on the official Single Entry Time Reporting (SETR) time and dance (T/A) record. If the tour of duty establishes entitlement to night differential and/or Sunday premium pay, the SETR T/A record must be accordingly. (

) Regular Overtime - If applicable, the tour of duty shall specify, by calendar and number of hours each day, overtime that is a part of an employee’s regularly scheduled administrative workweek. Regularly scheduled overtime planned and recorded in increments of
minutes. Compensation for regular overtime is referenced in IRM
and IRM

) Irregular or Occasional Overtime - At various times, a manager may identify the need to perform overtime work in advance of any given administrative workweek. This is defined as irregular or occasional overtime work and is reflected in the employee’s established tour of duty. Compensation for or occasional overtime is referenced in IRM
and IRM

a. Senior Executive Service (SES) Members (including those employees serving in SES positions) who report to Deputy Division Commissioners, Deputy Division Chiefs, Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate, Deputy Com

missioner for Modernization/Chief Information Officer, for employees their supervision and control; and, b. SES Members (including those employees serving in SES positions) who report directly to National Headquarters Deputy Directors and Deputy Chiefs for employees under their supervision and control. c. This authority may not be redelegated.

Irregular or Occasional Overtime - At various times, a manager may identify the need to perform overtime work in advance of any given administrative workweek. This is defined as irregular or occasional overtime work and is not reflected in the employee’s established tour of duty. Compensation for irregular or occasional overtime is referenced in IRM 6.500. 1.11 and IRM 6.500.1.12.

) Part-time Employees - The tour of duty must be annotated on the SF
, fication of Personnel Action of a part time employee (e.g., ″Tour of duty a.m. to
p.m., Monday through Friday.″) (

) Changes in work schedules, e.g., from part-time to full-time; full-time to time; seasonal to full-time, are based on management consideration of Work factors as the type of work performed, the number of employees necessary and Tours of have on duty, when work assignments will occur, as well as budgetary and ceiling requirements. (

) All changes in work schedules and tours of duty, whether permanent or temporary, must be documented and made a matter of record. Notices of changes in tours of duty, including any resulting changes in premium pay, be provided in writing to employees at least one pay period in advance of first pay period of the tour. In the event that unusual circumstances render such early notification impracticable, employees must be informed far in advance so that they will have time to report to work at the start of their tour. For bargaining unit employees, the negotiated agreement should be consulted regarding work schedule and tour of duty changes. (
) Adverse action or reduction in force procedures may apply to changes involving a decrease in hours worked. (
) For part-time employees, increases or decreases in tour of duty hours are be appropriately documented on a Standard Form
unless the tour of change in hours will be effective for two pay periods or less. (See IRM
,Establishing and Changing Part-time Tours of Duty.) (

) Tours necessitated by operating conditions - Tours of duty may vary to Saturday and Sunday or other changes to the standard work week to fulfill to the mission of the organization or increase cost efficiency. If feasible, such Schedule should provide for the same hours of work for each day, and for two tive days off in each administrative workweek. (

) Religious conviction - Employees may request a variance to their tour of due to religious observance or requirements (e.g., employees may have a religious requirement that prohibits work on Saturday or Sunday). This deviation is based upon an ongoing requirement and not a specific observance. For information regarding compensatory time for religious vances, see IRM
, Compensatory Time Off for Religious Observances. (
) A special tour of duty may be approved to allow employees to take one or more courses at a college, university, or other educational institution (in of Work dance with
CFR
), only if: for a. The coursework, when completed, will equip the employee to perform Purposes more effective work in the Service; b. The course is not training under
U.S.C. chapter
; and c. The rearrangement of the employee’s tour will not interfere with the complishment of required work, the work accomplishment of other employees, or result in additional costs.
The coursework, when completed, will equip the employee to perform more effective work in the Service; The course is not training under

; and The rearrangement of the employee’s tour will not interfere with the ac- complishment of required work, the work accomplishment of other employees, or result in additional costs.

) The employee may not receive any premium pay as a result of the special of duty which causes the employee to work on a day or at a time for which premium pay would be payable. This includes overtime, night differential, and/or Sunday pay. (

CFR
(e), the official ordering the travel shall record the reasons for the travel during non-duty hours and shall, when requested, provide a copy the statement to the employee concerned. (

) A lunch or other meal period is an approved period of time, from

minutes not to exceed one hour, in a nonpay and nonwork status that interrupts a workday or a period of overtime work for the purpose of permitting to eat or engage in permitted personal activities. Lunch or meal period schedules may vary by office based upon work requirements and availability and convenience of eating establishments. A lunch or meal period is scheduled approximately midway through an employee’s work day (
) Employees whose daily tour of duty is for six hours or more are required to have a lunch or meal period included in their daily tour of duty. (
) Employees may not work through their lunch period and leave work early lunch periods are not considered hours of work (
) A break is a short rest period (not to exceed

minutes) with pay in the workday during which employees are permitted to interrupt work for the of fatigue. For bargaining unit employees, breaks are subject to provisions stated in the negotiated agreement. (
) Break times may not be aggregated or used to shorten or otherwise change employee’s tour of duty. As such, a lunch or break may not be authorized at the end of the employee’s tour of duty. (
) Employees may not take more than two
minute breaks in any eight hour workday. (

) Combining a lunch or meal period with authorized paid breaks or rest is prohibited. Employees may not extend a lunch period by taking a break to or immediately following lunch, since the break is considered part of the ployee’s compensable workday. Internal Revenue Manual

) The President and Congress are the sole authorities able to grant a Federal holiday or to grant time off that has the effect of a holiday (
) For employees of the IRS, holidays will be identified and determined as provided by
U.S.C.
and

) Full-time employees who are not required to work on a holiday receive their rate of basic pay for the applicable number of holiday hours. On a holiday, employees on
hour/
-day week (standard tour of duty) and flexible work schedules, are paid for eight hours, which are considered part of the
-hour basic workweek. (

) Employees under a compressed work schedule are excused from all of the nonovertime holiday hours they would otherwise work on that day and which apply to their “basic work requirement.” For example, if a holiday falls on a
- or
-hour basic workday, the employee’s holiday is
or
hours (

) Part-time employees are entitled to a holiday when the holiday falls on a day when otherwise they would be required to work. Part-time employees who are excused from work on a holiday receive their rate of basic pay for the hours they are regularly scheduled to work on that day. For example, a part-time employee who is regularly scheduled to work from
a.m. to
p.m. on Mondays, will receive four hours of basic pay if Monday is a Federal holiday. (
) Intermittent employees do not have a regularly scheduled tour of duty and are not entitled to pay for the holiday. (

) Holidays do not affect setting of the basic workweek. In other words, must not reschedule an employee either to deny or confer holiday benefits or to shift work from a holiday to a day outside the basic workweek (one of the employee’s usual days off). (

and Executive Order

, authorizes ″in lieu of″ holidays (ILOH) for full-time employees when a holiday falls on a nonworkday. For tional information regarding “in lieu of” holidays, see http://www.opm.gov/oca/ worksch/html/holiday.asp#I
ieuo

olidays. a. Offices are closed to public business on Federal holidays. When a holiday falls on a Saturday, offices are closed on the preceding Friday and the ILOH is Friday; when a holiday falls on a Sunday, offices are closed on the following Monday and the ILOH is Monday. b. An ILOH is authorized only for a holiday designated in
U.S.C.
(a). Under
U.S.C.

(c), an ILOH is not authorized when Inauguration falls on an employee’s regularly scheduled nonwork day c. Part-time employees are not entitled to an ILOH when a holiday falls on a nonwork day and the ILOH occurs on a day a part-time employee is not regularly scheduled to work. However, part-time employees are excused from work without charge to leave or loss of pay for an ILOH granted to full-time employees on a day falling within the part-time employee’s regularly scheduled workweek. For example, when a holiday falls on a Saturday and the ILOH is Friday, a part-time employee will be entitled to an ILOH if regularly scheduled to work on a Friday. d. State and local holidays are not holidays within the meaning of
U.S.C.
An ILOH is not authorized when a state or local holiday occurs on employees’ regularly scheduled nonwork days. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Employees under a compressed work schedule are excused from all of the nonovertime holiday hours they would otherwise work on that day and which apply to their “basic work requirement.” For example, if a holiday falls on a 9- or 10-hour basic workday, the employee’s holiday is 9 or 10 hours respectively.

) When the holiday is observed at the beginning of a workday which encom- passes two calendar days, the holiday is observed for the entire tour (e.g., a nightshift that begins at
p.m. and ends at
a.m. the following day, the entire shift is considered the holiday). (
) For guidance regarding pay for work performed on a holiday, see IRM
, Pay for Holiday Work. (

) When a holiday falls on a regular nonworkday of an employee whose basic workweek is other than Monday through Friday, then the following rules of Holiday (ILOH) a. If the holiday falls on the employee’s administratively scheduled and “Saturday,” then the holiday is observed on the workday immediately Work preceding the holiday, (e.g., Monday is the administratively scheduled “Saturday” for an employee on a Wednesday – Sunday tour. If a falls on Monday, their ILOH would be Sunday). b. If the holiday falls on the employee’s administratively scheduled then the holiday is observed on the workday immediately succeeding holiday, (e.g., Tuesday is the administratively scheduled “Sunday” for employee on a Wednesday – Sunday tour. If a holiday falls on the employee’s ILOH would be Wednesday). (

) The regular day off (RDO) for employees on compressed work schedules not move; however, the holiday does. Therefore, if the holiday falls on an ployee’s RDO, the employee would be entitled to an ILOH. The ILOH would determined in accordance with IRM
(e.g., An employee on a

compressed schedule has a first Monday RDO. If the holiday is on Monday, the employee’s ILOH is the preceding Friday. If the holiday is on Sunday, employee’s ILOH is the Tuesday following the Monday RDO). (
) When the initial ILOH is preempted by inclement weather or other office closure, an alternate ILOH will not be observed. See IRM
for guidance regarding excused absence for building closure. (

U.S.C.
states that employees are entitled to a day of pay when prevented from working solely because of the occurrence of a legal public holiday. (

) Employees must be in a pay status or a paid time off status (i.e., leave, pensatory time off, compensatory time off for travel, or credit hours) on their scheduled workdays either before or after a holiday in order to be entitled their regular pay for that day. The fact that an employee is in pay status at least one of the days surrounding the holiday establishes a basis to that the employee would have reported for duty, but for the holiday (
Gen.
and
Comp. Gen.

). a. For full-time employees, if a holiday immediately precedes or follows a period of Leave Without Pay (LWOP) or Absence Without Leave but the employee is in pay status either the workday before or the workday after the holiday, the employee receives pay for the holiday. b. When an employee is on LWOP or AWOL the last workday preceding a holiday and the first workday following the holiday, the employee is not entitled to pay for the holiday. c. A new employee who enters on duty and takes the oath of office the following a holiday (with an appointment effective date after the not entitled to pay for the holiday as the employee was not an IRS employee on the holiday. (

) The decision to pay a seasonal employee for a holiday must be reviewed against the criteria that: (a) an employee is on the rolls both the day before and the day after the holiday; (b) the employee is in a pay status before or after the holiday; and (c) there must be work to be performed in order to presume the employee would have worked, but for the holiday (Comp. B-

). It cannot be presumed that a seasonal employee would have worked but for the holiday when there is no work to be performed. a. If a seasonal employee is released from duty the last workday before a holiday due to the non-availability of work, they are not entitled to sation for the holiday. This is because they were not prevented from working solely because of the holiday.

The fact that an employee is in pay status at least one of the days surrounding the holiday establishes a basis to presume that the employee would have reported for duty, but for the holiday (

a. For full

time employees, if a holiday immediately precedes or follows a period of Leave Without Pay (LWOP) or Absence Without Leave (AWOL) but the employee is in pay status either the workday before or the workday after the holiday, the employee receives pay for the holiday. b. When an employee is on LWOP or AWOL the last workday preceding a holiday and the first workday following the holiday, the employee is not entitled to pay for the holiday. c. A new employee who enters on duty and takes the oath of office the day following a holiday (with an appointment effective date after the holiday), not entitled to pay for the holiday as the employee was not an IRS employee on the holiday.
a. If a seasonal employee is released from duty the last workday before a holiday due to the non
availability of work, they are not entitled to compen
sation for the holiday. This is because they were not prevented from working solely because of the holiday.
of Duty and Work Scheduling 6.610.1

A seasonal employee released from duty the last workday before a holiday due to the non-availability of work may not use annual leave to take them through the holiday and get paid for the holiday (Comp. Gen. B-193821)

) Per the authorities below, an agency head or designated official may absence from duty without loss of pay or charge to leave. This excused absence is not leave. However, the term ″administrative leave,” while not offi- cially recognized in legislation or executive regulations, is used to refer to an authorized absence from duty with pay and without charge to leave. The term “administrative leave” allows agencies to charge excused absence to the ap- propriate T/A codes in order to correctly pay employees for fulfilling their workweek. (
) Under
U.S.C.
, and
CFR Part
, Subpart C; Order
CG
CG

), an authorized official may administratively dismiss or excuse the absence of employees without of pay or charge to leave when: a. Normal operations are interrupted by events beyond the control of man- agement or employees (e.g., office flood); b. The closing of an entire work unit or a portion thereof for short periods of time is required or in the best interest of the Service (e.g., inclement weather). c. It is in the public interest to relieve employees from work to participate in civil activities, which the Government is interested in encouraging (i.e., voting, blood donations, bone marrow or organ donations).

It is in the public interest to relieve employees from work to participate civil activities, which the Government is interested in encouraging (i.e., voting, blood donations, bone marrow or organ donations). a.m.), excused absence is only granted to those employees who report for The intent of the excused absence is to allow time for additional traffic, bad road conditions, delayed public transportation, etc. Employees who not attempt to report to work but request to use annual leave, credit or compensatory time are not granted excused absence. b. agement or employees (e.g., office flood); b. (08-14-2009) Excused Absence and Administrative - Authorities
a. In a situation where an authorized official determines a late arrival, either by number of hours or actual clock time (i.e., two hours or

a.m.), excused absence is only granted to those employees who report for duty. The intent of the excused absence is to allow time for additional traffic, bad road conditions, delayed public transportation, etc. Employees who do not attempt to report to work but request to use annual leave, credit hours, or compensatory time are not granted excused absence. b. Employees at an alternate worksite (telework site) when their office is closed are not granted excused absence unless the condition which impacted the office also impacts the telework site and prevents employees from performing work (e.g., power outage).

Hours of c. Employees at a telework site who experience an emergency situation (e.g., power outage) which has not impacted the official duty station contact their manager. Employees may be directed to report to the duty station or another alternate worksite to complete their workday. (

) When the office is not closed, an employee who has made reasonable to report to work but is unable to report due to emergency conditions may eligible for a limited amount of excused absence for part or all of the ee’s workday. An acceptable explanation and/or documentation must be submitted that addresses efforts the employee made to reach work; modes of transportation; highway conditions; commuting distance; and any other evidence that substantiates the inability to report for work. Factors will be considered upon reviewing the request are availability of telework, whether or not the employee’s residence is outside the normal commuting area, mode of transportation typically used by the employee, efforts by the employee to report to work, the success of other employees similarly physical disability of the employee, and local travel restrictions. (

) If the President, the Office of Personnel Management, or other appropriate authority declares a natural disaster area, employees who are faced with a personal emergency caused by that natural disaster may be eligible for a sonable amount (typically not exceeding three consecutive workdays) of excused absence, based on the facts and circumstances of the personal emergency. Such requests will be reviewed on a case by case basis and approved through the management chain by the business unit executive, in consultation and coordination as appropriate, with the Senior Representative (SCR). An employee requesting such excused absence will requested to provide an explanation and/or documentation in support of the claim. Factors which shall be considered are the nature of the personal emergency, efforts by the employee to come to work, local travel restrictions, other employees in similar situations, and the availability of other options as an interim telework agreement or reporting to another POD on a basis (

) Additional emergency guidance for managers and employees will be through Service communication channels from the Office of the Deputy Commissioner or IRS Human Capital Officer for incidents that impact significant portions of the Service and over extensive periods of time (e.g., ricanes, pandemic influenza). (

) During severe weather or other emergency situations various Federal, State other officials with jurisdiction (e.g., local government not the Red Cross) request that IRS employees assist in emergency law enforcement, relief, or clean-up efforts. In such situations, employees may be approved by the business unit executive, a limited amount of excused absence to participate a civilian capacity during official duty hours. a. Employees must provide documentation from the authorized that includes the requested duration of service. b. The employee’s absence does not impact the operations of the office approval is subject to workload considerations. c. A written statement is submitted from the organization that documents actual dates and hours of work.

Note: This policy does not apply to Federal employees who are members of the National Guard or Reserves who are called up to assist in disaster relief and recovery efforts, since they are entitled to military leave under 5 U.S.C. 6323

Managers may grant employees limited excused absence only if needed, to vote in Federal, State, county, or municipal elections or in referendums on a civic matter in their community provided that such time off does not seriously interfere with workload accomplishment. Polling places throughout the United States are usually open for extended periods of time, and excused absence should rarely be needed. Requests for excused absence for voting purposes must be submitted in advance to the immediate manager. Managers may request that employees identify their tour of duty, the time the polls open and close, and why excused absence is needed in order to be able to vote.

a. Where the polls are not open at least three hours either before or after an employee’s regular work hours, a limited amount of excused absence may be granted to permit the employee to report for work three hours after the polls open or leave from work three hours before the polls close, whichever requires the lesser amount of time off. For example, if polls are open from
a.m. to
p.m., excused absence may be approved, if needed as follows:

Tour of Duty Maximum Excused Absence (Polls open 6:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.) 7:00 a.m. to 3:45 p.m. None 7:00 a.m. to 4:45 p.m. 15 minutes (end of day) 7:15 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. None 7:15 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. 30 minutes (end of day) 7:30 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. None 7:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m. 45 minutes (end of day) 7:45 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. None 7:45 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. One hour (end of day) 8:00 a.m. to 4:45 p.m. 15 minutes (end of day) 8:00 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. One hour and 15 minutes (end of day) 8:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m. 45 minutes (end of day) 9:00 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. 30 minutes (beginning of day)

If an employee’s voting place is beyond normal commuting distance such that the employee cannot vote within the three hour time frame as noted above, and vote by absentee ballot is not permitted, excused absence (not to exceed one day) may be granted to allow the employee to make the trip to the voting place to cast a ballot. If more than one day is needed, the employee may request annual leave or LWOP for the additional period of absence.

) For employees who vote in jurisdictions which require registration in person, time off to register may be granted on substantially the same basis as for voting, however no excused absence shall be granted if registration can be accomplished on a nonwork day and the place of registration is within a rea- sonable one day round trip travel distance of the employee’s residence. (

) Employees who volunteer to donate blood and/or make aphaeresis (platelet) donations without compensation to the American Red Cross or to other banks, or respond to calls for blood donations are entitled to up to four hours of excused absence for recuperative purposes. a. Excused absence may be granted for travel to and from the donation and to actually give blood. b. Full-time and part-time employees may be granted excused absence for recuperative purposes only for the time that coincides with their normal tour of duty (e.g., three hours is granted to an employee whose tour of duty ends three hours following the donation.) The excused absence be taken immediately following the blood donation as the intent of the excused absence is for recuperation. Employees may not donate blood, return to work, and subsequently use excused absence later that day or on another day. Similarly, employees may not use excused absence in advance of their blood donation. c. At the end of the four hour recuperative period, employees are expected to return to work. If unable to return to work due to circumstances to donating blood, managers may grant additional excused absence for recuperation not to exceed the remaining scheduled hours of duty on day of the blood donation. In granting such additional excused absence, managers must consider each request on a case by case basis. If the employee remains at the blood donation site to recuperate, or is at an facility, a medical authority may be available to assist the manager in making a decision. If a medical authority is not available, the manager must decide whether to grant any additional excused absence based the information provided by the employee. d. When bloodmobiles are available locally, arrangements should be made for donations at the office instead of sending employees to blood donor centers. e. Employees who are not accepted for donating blood are only entitled to excused absence for travel to and from the donation site and the time needed to make the determination. (

Since aphaeresis donations may be given more frequently, granting excused time for such donations is discretionary, subject to workload considerations. (

employees are entitled to excused for bone marrow or organ donation. a. Bone Marrow - Employees will be granted up to seven days excused absence each calendar year for bone marrow donation. b. Organ Donor - Employees will be granted up to

) The maximum authorized excused absence includes the time required for travel, testing to determine if the employee is a compatible donor, plus the required to undergo the bone marrow donation or transplant procedure and recuperate. (

) Medical documentation must be submitted in advance of the bone marrow or organ donation and support the request for excused absence. This tion will be an official statement from a medical facility or physician and will indicate the period of absence required for the compatibility test, donation or transplant procedure, and recuperation. (

) Employees in a work status will be excused without charge to leave or loss pay, when they are required to take a test, assessment, interview, or any and evaluative process as a result of applying under an internal or external IRS vacancy announcement. Scheduling of the time must be approved by the manager and subject to workload considerations. Excused absence includes travel time. (

) Part-time employees not scheduled to work at the time of the examination seasonal employees in nonwork status are not authorized excused absence. Intermittent employees, as they do not have a regularly scheduled tour of are ineligible for such excused time. (
) Employees who are applying for a position outside of the IRS are not entitled to excused absence. However, upon request, employees may be granted annual leave or LWOP. (

) Employees required by the Service to undergo a medical examination or testing remain in duty status during the time needed for these purposes. Employees in nonwork status will not be placed in work status for the of such medical examination or testing. (

) It is in the best interest of the Service for employees to attain professional tifications in their occupational field as it adds to the technical expertise and professional stature of our employees. Thus employees as noted below may be granted excused absence to sit for the examinations/certification process for admission to the Bar, Certified Public Accountant (CPA), Certified Benefit Specialist (CEBS), Certified Management Accountant (CMA), or Certified Internal Auditor (CIA) certificate, State-Certified General Appraiser, Professional Engineer’s license, or membership as an Associate or Fellow in the American Society of Pension Actuaries. (

) Internal Revenue Agents, Criminal Investigators, Estate Tax Examiners, Appellate Auditors, Estate Tax Attorneys, Revenue Officers, Tax Compliance Officers, Appeals Officers, Tax Law Specialists, Accountants, Engineers, Real Estate Appraisers, or HCO Human Resources Specialists may be administra- tively excused to take the CPA, CEBS, CMA, CIA, State-Certified General Appraiser, Professional Engineer, Bar, or actuarial examinations up to four times, if necessary. The excused absence includes travel time on the day of the examination, and if applicable, time to appear at an oral interview as a prerequisite to being sworn in or licensed in the profession. (

) The Service recognizes the need for excellence and technical efficiency in computer field and therefore, excused absence may also be granted for spe- cialized professional examinations in the computer field. Internal Revenue Manual

) Employees will be granted excused absence to attend a tax audit that: a. is required as a condition of employment; or b. results from an investigation by the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA). (
) Employees will also be granted excused absence to discuss an employee’s personal tax affairs with a member of TIGTA or other authorized official. (

) Under certain conditions, excused absence may be authorized to attend meetings and conferences. Guidance may be found at the following link: hco.web.irs.gov/devtrain/training/servlearn/trainconf.html. (

Employees may be permitted up to eight hours of excused absence per calendar year to volunteer their time to legitimate public service organizations. Such excused absence is approved under very limited circumstances and in accordance with the following:

, employees who return from military service in support of the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) are Active to five days of excused absence each time they return from active military duty. In order to receive the five days of excused absence, employees must spend at least
consecutive days on active duty in support of the GWOT. returning employee is entitled to this excused absence only once during a month period, with a new

-month period beginning after the first use of excused absence. Detailed information regarding the requirements and dures may be found at OPM, Questions and Answers on Excused Absence Employees Returning from Active Duty in the Global War on Terrorism, www.opm.gov/oca/compmemo/

This excused absence must be used for benefits counseling sponsored by the Federal Government or National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU). For example, if an employee is covered by a spouse’s health insurance plan at a private company, the employee not be granted excused absence to attend a health benefits fair at the private company. c. hours of excused absence per calendar year to participate in self-directed training approved in an Indi- vidual Employee Development Plan (IDP).

, employees who return from active military service in support of the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) are entitled to five days of excused absence each time they return from active military duty. In order to receive the five days of excused absence, employees must spend at least

military service in support of the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) are entitled to five days of excused absence each time they return from active military duty. In order to receive the five days of excused absence, employees must spend at least 42 consecutive days on active duty in support of the GWOT. A returning employee is entitled to this excused absence only once during a 12- month period, with a new 12-month period beginning after the first use of the excused absence. Detailed information regarding the requirements and proce- dures may be found at OPM, Questions and Answers on Excused Absence Employees Returning from Active Duty in the Global War on Terrorism, http:// www.opm.gov/oca/compmemo/2008/2008-21-QA.asp.

Employees may be excused from duty to attend one IRS retirement planning program if they are within six years of eligibility for optional ment. Employees may be excused from duty for a limited time (up to four hours per calendar year) for benefits counseling to attend a health benefits fair, review health benefit information, seek financial counseling or additional retirement counseling. This excused absence must be used for benefits counseling sponsored by the Federal Government or National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU). For example, if an employee is covered by a spouse’s health insurance plan at a private company, the employee may not be granted excused absence to attend a health benefits fair at the private company. Employees may be allowed up to one hour of excused absence plus time to meet with an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) counselor (up to four sessions per calendar year). ) Under the Flexitour with Credit Hours work schedule, the employee works established eight hour daily tour of duty for five days each week of the pay period with the employee selecting starting and ending times within the hours. Once selected, the hours are fixed until an opportunity is provided to select different starting and stopping times. However, employees may earn use credit hours. Credit hours are any hours that are voluntarily worked managerial approval) in excess of an employee’s basic work requirement (eight hours per day,
hours per week, and

hours per pay period for a full-time employee). Credit hours earned can be subsequently used at the election of the employee and with managerial approval to vary the length of work day or work week. (
) CWS are fixed work schedules that enable employees to complete their biweekly work requirement in less than
workdays.

There are two categories of AWS: Flexible Work Schedules (FWS) and Com- pressed Work Schedules (CWS). Within FWS and CWS, there are various schedules available. The only allowable FWS within IRS is Flexitour with Credit Hours. The allowable CWS within IRS are 5/4-9 and 4/10.
CWS are fixed work schedules that enable employees to complete their basic biweekly work requirement in less than 10 workdays.

) An employee may not elect to work and earn credit hours during his/her regularly scheduled duty hours on a holiday as the employee is already compensated for that time. (

) An employee may not earn credit hours during the hours of his/her scheduled duty hours while on excused absence, such as hours excused work because of a weather emergency. If an office closure does not impact employee’s telework site or alternate post of duty, the employee is required work and regular work hours are posted. (

) Credit hours may not be earned solely for the purpose of traveling. employees who elect to perform essential work outside of the basic while in travel status, may earn credit hours with prior managerial approval. a. An employee may be required to work while traveling during regularly scheduled duty hours. When so required, the employee will receive no additional compensation and is not eligible to earn credit hours. Such hours worked are considered regular work hours. (

) Night pay may not be paid when credit hours are earned or used at night. When employees earn or use credit hours, they are not performing scheduled work. Night pay is only authorized for work performed at night during an employee’s regularly scheduled tour of duty. (
) Sunday premium pay may not be paid when employees earn or use credit hours on a Sunday. (

) To participate in AWS, an employee must have at least a fully successful formance evaluation. Employees without a rating of record will be be rated as “Fully Successful” in order to be eligible for AWS. If an rated less than “Fully Successful,” his or her manager may move the off their current AWS work schedule. (

) Employees selected for work assignments outside of their office (to include training, details, promotions/temporary promotions) may be required to tinue their AWS (either temporarily or permanently, as appropriate) in order comply with established work schedules of the assignment or work group. example, if an employee on a

to

) If an employee is no longer subject to a flexible work schedule (federal ployment ends, transfers to another agency, converts to a compressed schedule, etc.), the employee is entitled to payment up to a maximum of unused earned credit hours for full-time employees (or up to a part-time ployee’s maximum based upon tour of duty).

Credit hours may not be earned solely for the purpose of traveling. However, employees who elect to perform essential work outside of the basic workweek while in travel status, may earn credit hours with prior managerial approval.
